review_blob: 355ml bottle. BEST Russian Imperial Stout I've ever tasted. Which says a lot since it's one of my favourite styles. Deep dark ink colour with orange head. Smells of dusty books. Tastes are dark chocolate and espresso. Not sweet in the least. Man this is good. How can we find more??

355 ml bottle. Served cold in pint glass. 1/4" loamy head. Cinnamon orange colour with slight aroma of dark fruits and rain water. Bursting with flavour (totally wasn't expecting that)!!
Wow, it's super malty with a banana bread sweetness and short aftertaste. Perfect carbonation and squeaky clean palate. I like!!

750ml bottle. Ashamed to say I drank it all by myself! (In one evening!)
Great aroma of cocoa/dark chocolate. Not much head compared to their other chocolate stout (BNL). This one is pretty sweet though. Can't deny the chocolate milk component, but she's a tad sweet. Much sweeter than their Bare Naked Ladies collab beer last season. Smooth thick palate works well with this one.

750ml bottle. The perfect Christmas sipper. Enjoyed by the tree (but only half the bottle). Small head. Barely any aroma. This is a much subtler brew than the name might suggest. The double chocolate is not a separate component from the cranberry - rather, the two flavours meld to create a rounded toasty malt that uniformly finishes with a slight sweet tang. Everything is subtle. No overpowering or cloying aftertaste. Warming and potent.
beer_name: Muskoka Winter Beard Double Chocolate Cranberry Stout

review_blob: 650ml bottle. A good Christmas time brew. Pours with little head. Dark rich brown. No real aroma. Soft palate, nutty roasted taste. Subtle yet appreciable.

22oz. Draught at Pearson Airport. The on-tap version was a little better than the can I had. Vibrant and hoppy, but not overly bitter. Long aftertaste. Slakes a thirst! Nice brown gold colouring with little to no head. I'd order this again
beer_name: Creemore Springs Mad & Noisy Hops & Bolts India Pale Lager

review_blob: UPDATED: DEC 4, 2013
beer_name: Flying Monkeys / Central City Red on Red

review_blob:
440ml can. Incredible tan marshmallow head which, I warn you, due to the nitrogen charge explodes out of the can. Every can's a mess. And every can's worth it!!
Takes some time for it to calm down, but the milkshake body is a real treat. Aroma is subtle - cream, toffee, chocolate and unquestionably vanilla. 
Taste is sweet and malty but not cloyingly so. Again, unquestionably vanilla. Texture is thick and palate is wet. Very enjoyable beer.

355ml bottle. Pours with little to no head. Warm orange brown brew with mild, negligible aroma. Taste is successfully pumpkin pie with a warming cinnamon finish. Fairly crisp and clean for a wheat beer (which I find usually chalky). Decent seasonal!
beer_name: Mill Street Nightmare on Mill Street Pumpkin Ale

review_blob: 750ml bottle shared with friend by the campfire. Skunky aroma - wet dog and wax crayons. Really fizzy head which loudly crackles and then disappears. Good level of carbonation. Alcoholy taste with hoppy yet sweet finish. Not overly complex.
UPDATED: AUG 19, 2013

355ml bottle. So happy to find this brew in an American grocery store when I hopped the border one night. I love New Belgium Brewery and always wanted to try this one. It doesn't disappoint! 8.5% alcohol!!! Like the deScription says, it's got it all - sweet, bitter, perfect balance. Great finish. No complaints here! Nice deep head. Citrus and pine aroma. Deep gold (Lovibond 10) colour. Perfect carbonation. Lots of lace. A bit of a stronger alcohol flavour than its regular IPA brother, Ranger. This beer packs many punches.

473ml can from Waterloo variety pack. 
Pours a dish detergent sudsy head - pale yellow body with active carbonation. The aroma is of sweet hay and cheap booze. Quite unappealing to be honest. Like corn and cereal and cardboard. Taste is bland - there's a spiciness in the aftertaste but this is about the dullest most boring beer I've had. Disappointing. Dry palate. Good carbonation.
beer_name: Brick Waterloo Jack Pine Belgian Ale

review_blob: UPDATED: DEC 4, 2014

341ml bottle. Pours a reddish amber with thin creamy vanilla head. No distinctive aroma. Taste is fantastic!! Not a west coast IPA but still a hoppy treat! Sooo buttery smooth yet crisp level of carbonation for a perfect palate. Excellent balance. Their best offering.

650ml bottle from LCBO. Pours a deep gold (Lovibond 6) with loose thin head. Nice lace. Aroma is of citrus and hops. Taste is very hoppy like grapefruits - not much of its namesake in here though (pine). Very smooth and well balanced. Good level of carbonation. Squeaky clean palate. I'm impressed.

Squat 355ml bottle - ya, you know the one. Man, you guys are tough on the ol' Mickeys in here. I was actually pleasantly surprised by bits drinkability and presentation. Nice head, good retention. No aroma (so no skunky badness). Served ice cold, this really did the trick! Slightly sweet finish - just great after mowing the lawn. Went down too fast! And 5.5%! C'mon, where's the love?

330ml bottle. Faint aroma, though thankfully none of the typical I&G skunkiness. Pours a silky tight tan head which surprised me as well. Lots of lace. Tawny amber (Lovibond 16) with perfect clarity. Taste is bold!! Malty and sweet like caramel with a hint of the unique wood aging taste of their regular oak barrel fare. Actually very surprised at the results here. This turns out to be their best outing yet!!

341ml bottle from variety pack. Pours a minimal head with nice lacing qualities. Colour is hazy caramel (Lovibond 20). Aroma is intensely complex - pine, peat, berries, sarsaparilla and citrus. Taste is initially hoppy, with a wet, earthy undertone. Greasy/wet palate. Gives way to sweeter, hay and citrusy aftertaste. Medium to long finish. Decent beer!

341ml bottle. From a 49 Parallel variety pack. Gentle pour creates 1/4" meringue head. Sweet citrus aroma. Taste is lightly sweet initially, predominantly of oranges, then a nice hoppy bitter taste punches through for a grapefruit finish. Not complicated - but gratifyingly easy drinking. A fine summer beverage!

750ml bottle on special Ed. Box. One left at the LCBO so I bought it. Aroma is distinctly citrusy. Some spice on the nose. Pours a hazy yellow orange (Lovibond 7) with 2" frothy head. Slight lace. A bright bitter kick to start, rounding to a sweet perfectly balanced malty swallow. Then the aftertaste. Man, where to begin. Spicy, leathery, grape fruity, and piney with a long long life afterward on the tongue. Hard not to go for another swig. Delightful, and another fabulous beer in the Monkeys fashion.
beer_name: Flying Monkeys Matador Cedar Aged Double IPA

review_blob: UPDATED: APR 19, 2013
500ml bottle. Pours with creamy thick head and lace. Burgundy brown elixir. No real aroma. Taste is somewhat underwhelming. Some malty, biscuity sweetness and dark fruits, but nothing special here.
UPDATED: MAR 8, 2013

12oz. Bottle. Pours a red amber colour (Lovibond 10/11) with voluminous, soapy head. Aroma is slight, but floral and honey-sweet. Gorgeous action in the glass. Toffee sweet initial taste turns to a citrus hoppy bitterness which finishes to a long clean bittersweet piney aftertaste. Very malty and yet that bitter finish is extremely effective as a balance. What a great IPA.
beer_name: Samuel Adams Third Voyage Double IPA

review_blob: 12oz. Bottle. Pours a derp burgundy (Lovibond 34/35) with a luscious deep tan head. No discernible aroma. Very smooth, watery palate with taste of some dark chocolate with hoppier finish. Really more like a porter. Sticky, thorough lacing. Great brew! Sam Adams never ceases to impress me.

12oz. Bottle. Belgian IPA? Did they make that up? Certainly smells distinctly like Belgian ale and pours similarly - orange gold (Lovibond 15) colour with small head. Fizz lacing. Taste is also Belgian. Not sure where the IPA comes in, as I'm not really appreciating the piney, bitter taste associated with American IPAs. This is Belgian earthy, malty alcoholic tasting with subtle hops to balance it all. Very good beer though!

355 ml bottle.  Well kids, they don't really come any better than this! And from Ontario to boot!! Pours a yellow, effervescent brew (Lovibond 11) with 1/2" foam head. Really lacey as well. Aromas of the greenest pine needles and of flowers! Maybe even some notes of fresh baked cookies. Taste... Just wow! Bright bitter hops initially then a sweet, malty, slightly heady alcohol flavour balanced by a grassy, piney flair as it finishes. Long aftertaste is sumptuous, leaving you wanting the next sip. Less bitter (hoppy) than the original Mad Tom, but much more refined and satisfying. I compare it to the Digfish Head 90min IPA (which is #1 IPA on America right now). It's actually better! Now I must rush back and buy more. MUCH more!
beer_name: Muskoka Twice As Mad Tom IPA

beer_brewer_name: Leinenkugel Brewing Company (Tenth & Blake Beer Co.)
review_blob: 355ml bottle. Pours a deep, clear, ruby-brown (Lovibond 28) with a silky 1/2" head. Aroma of plums, vanilla and chocolate. Thin lacing. Palate is velvety, yet not thick - watery, but not thin. Low carbonation. Initially sweet, with a roasted nutty finish. Typical porter perhaps. But still quite good. Not as much vanilla in the flavouring as I had expected or hoped.

750ml bottle. Pours like a champagne. Fizzy, quickly dissipating head and no lace. Yellow gold (Lovibond 7) colour. Aroma is of Trappist yeast (like Chimay) and orange peels. Definitely a Belgian style. Tastes are complex and clamorous, though not out of balance - just complicated. Sweet and hoppy and bitter and malty and alcoholic. Carbonation is low to moderate. I expected more satisfaction from this.

12 oz. bottle. Have had this on draft and bottled. It's one of the best IPAs you can ever drink! Pours a murky golden orange with thick white head. Incredibly aromatic - and unique! I smell hints of dill, paprika, citrus and tropical fruit. The taste is absolutely loud and vibrantly addictive: grapefruit sweet, with guava notes as well as spicy, peppery currents in the aftertaste. Short, bitter aftertaste. Clean, dry palate. Excellent carbonation - perfect mouthfeel. Please try this beer!!
beer_name: Cigar City Jai Alai India Pale Ale

review_blob: 355 ml bottle. Pours a lusty red-orange with a thin head. Fuzzy lace. Aroma is floral, hops and apricots. Taste is subtle sweetness initially, then subdued bitterness. Quite refreshing and drinkable. Watery palate with a filmy mouthfeel. Medium to long bitter aftertaste.
beer_name: Samuel Smiths Organic / Old Brewery Pale Ale

review_blob: 12 oz. bottle. Pours a muddy, opaque brown-gold brew (Lovibond 20). Slight head and lace. Aroma is of a porter or stout! Hints of chocolate and malt. Actually, exactly like Count Chocula cereal. Taste is well balanced between being a wheat beer and pushing the porter envelope - has a wheat beer mouthfeel and watery palate, while offering slight notes of chocolate, hops and spice. A little on the flat side, but by far their best wheat beer offering.
beer_name: Shock Top End of the World Midnight Wheat

review_blob: 12 oz. bottle. Pours a very thin looking auburn yellow beer with 1/4" white head and a nice lace. Aroma is somewhat hoppy and mildly floral. Taste is not as bitter as one might expect from an American IPA but the fuggles are hoppy nonetheless. The aftertaste is a tad unpleasant but there's a good, clean mouthfeel and the carbonation is perfect. Refreshing and quenching. A little boring and simple.

473ml can. Pours a thin, clear gold (Lovibond 6/7) with 1/4" head. Soapy lace. Aroma is faintly citrus and flowers. Taste is not overly pleasant. Slight bitter hops, but takes a turn with a metallic bite and a bile aftertaste. The palate is watery, dull and mostly flat. First few sips are best. Subsequent ones are disappointing.
beer_name: Hop City Big Mouth Pale Ale

review_blob: 500ml can. Pours a clear, gold-ruby colour with adequate head and good lacing. Not a scent though. Taste is (obviously not American IPA) subdued and rather dull and watery. Still, refreshing and crisp. Good mouthfeel. Clean. It actually does have a mineral water taste - a metallic tang that slakes the thirst rather well! Pretty balanced. Just boring for the most part.

355ml bottle. Pours a hazy, marigold with puffy, cloud head. Beautiful beer. No aroma. Slight wheat beer taste but no chalky mouthfeel. Utterly refreshing and much too easy to drink! No hoppy or malty backbone just a clean, crisp taste of ale in perfect balance. I could pump these back all night!

500ml can. Pours an ultra-clear yellow (Lovibond 4/5) with small, loose, white head. Light hops fragrance. Taste is lightly sweet and lightly hoppy - grassy, corny and metallic. Somewhat unpleasant aftertaste. Filling too. Seems average for a lager. Watery palate.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a very hazy orange (Lovibond 10/11). Wonderfully messy, thick head and lace. Aroma is grapefruit and citrus. Taste is certainly not as hoppy as the label says ("kick-in-the-teeth hop-chop). It's bitter but not overly hoppy and it seems so only because there's not any maltiness in the mix. Quite simple and straightforward. Refreshing and clean drinking. Dry mouthfeel, with no long aftertaste.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a hazy, thick yellow (Lovibond 5/6) with 1/4" head. Scotch tape lacing around rim. Slightly sweet fruity aroma - very subtle. Taste is brightly bitter like grapefruit and pine but with that sweet apricot twist for some balance. Still finished quite bitter but what a fantastic IPA and a welcome surprise for being wheat beer! Good carbonation level for an excellent mouthfeel.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a murky apricot gold colour (Lovibond 6). Small head but messy, thorough lace. Barely any scent. Taste is huge though! Big, fruity initial explosion with an immediately strong bitter hoppy finish. Long grapefruit aftertaste. Medium carbonation. Good mouthfeel.

12oz. Bottle. Pours a tiny head and wet, loose lace. Very murky orange (Lovibond 16) colour. Obvious apricot nose with floral hints. Mildly sweet to start. Have to say, apricots aren't as full flavoured as some fruits so perhaps not the greatest choice; certainly taste the apricot but its underwhelming. Still, there's lots of hoppy bitterness for a dry, sharp finish. Great palate - good carbonation. Would be good in the summer.

12oz bottle pours golden tangerine yellow (Lovibond 6). Clear. 
Negligible aroma. Not unpleasant, just nothing notable. Slight head wet lace. 
Watery texture, metallic aftertaste. Tastes like paper. Newspaper. I think I detect the carbon too! Blech. 
Nothing really good to say so this review is done.

355ml bottle. Pours a deep golden red (Lovibond 16/17) with fluffy, voluminous head. Aroma is similar to Innis & Gunn offerings: oaky, malty and alcoholic. Taste is full and bold: lots of malt and equal blends if hop. Also a nutty undertone. Very powerfully strong tastes all vying for attention. Top marks for keeping a volatile blend so well balanced! Superb palate - good carbonation and clean, crisp mouthfeel.

500ml growler. Mead pours flatly into glass producing no head or lace. Fizzy though. Looks like ginger ale. Sweet honey scent. Tastes unlike honey though and similar to commercial ginger ale or 7up. Very flat. Somewhat disappointed there's no real honey taste.

12oz. can. Thanks to the used canning machine they got from New Belgium Breweries, this Cigar City Brew is as fresh as it was out of the tank! Pours a large, velour tan head which gradually makes a lacey blanket around the glass. Murky gold-brown (Lovibond 33/34). Very soft aroma of milk chocolate. Taste is bolder than expected - sweet milk duds then toasty malts, them slight bitterness in the aftertaste. Pretty complex! Velvety, smooth palate and medium weight for mouthfeel. Was expecting a nut brown and got an oatmeal stout!

12oz. Bottle. Pours a deep chestnut brown (Lovibond 39) with burgundy highlights. Decent head and velvety lace. Barely an aroma - slight chocolate sweetness on the nose. Taste is Chocolate and roasted nuts initially with a nice swing towards bitter yet mellow hops. Really nicely balanced. Similar to the Samuel Smith stout. Texture is thick with a soft, flatness.

12oz. Bottle. I have a bottle of 60 minute and the 90 minute here for the sake of comparison. They both look alike - same colouring, same head, etc. aroma also similar. Taste of the 60 is less robust and less malty and lacks the sweet finish of the 90. The 90 had much more depth I suppose. Great IPA but the 90 actually gets the nod. I like the balance and extra sweet character of the 90 minute.

355ml bottle. Pours a dark mahogany brew (Lovibond 36) with not much head or lace. Aroma is winey - sweet alcohol. Taste is... Fantastic.... Port wine (well, not as sweet as port) dominates. Dark fruits and spices with a real boozy undercurrent. I tasted black licorice and coca-cola. Which actually contributes nicely to this beer. Very unique. Very tasty. Very complex. Great palate.  Lots of carbonation which is surprising given the lack of head or lace. A favourite!

beer_brewer_name: Magic Hat Brewing Company (North American Breweries)
review_blob: 3/4 pint bottle. Pours an inky purple (Lovibond 40) with tight, 1/2" head. Messy lace. Aroma is indiscernible and unremarkable. Tastes like water mostly. Kind of disappointing actually. Sure there's a silky palate and a slight coffee-bitter aftertaste. But this is not on par with any of the dozens of good stouts I've had this season. Quite bland.
beer_name: Magic Hat Heart Of Darkness Stout (2012-)
